prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Order for Delivery Up or Preservation of Property

para.paratext: Where a moving party can satisfy the court that it owns or is authorized to use confidential information and that the information or copies of it have been appropriated by the offending party, the moving party may be entitled to interim recovery.[1]

An order for delivery up will require the offending party to deliver the material in question to the plaintiff or destroy it. The court in Ansell Rubber Co. Pty. Ltd. v. Allied Rubber Industries Pty. Ltd.[2] held that:

… the defendant company … should make a full and proper affidavit of what it holds, and that it should within a specified time dismantle the machines and deliver up the parts to the plaintiff for destruction. The nature of the parts … is such that they should not be left in the hands of the defendant company. They cannot, however, be retained or made use of by the plaintiff, which has no property in them.

A party will be able to move for an interim order for the recovery of property[3] or for the preservation of property,[4] with or without notice to the opposing party. In the Federal Court,[5] there is no general right to an interim order for recovery of property, although an order for the preservation of property that is the subject of an action may be obtained on notice to the opposing party.

On a motion for interim recovery of property, the moving party must provide affidavit evidence to satisfy the court that it owns or is entitled to use the confidential information and that the information is being unlawfully withheld by the offending party. If the court decides to grant the motion, it may order the moving party to post security in an amount equal to double the value of the confidential information appropriated, and order the sheriff to seize the property from the wrongdoer and deliver it to the moving party.[6]

An order for delivery up or destruction is generally ancillary to one of the other remedies, most often an order for injunctive relief. The reasoning behind such an order for delivery appears to be removal of the temptation to breach the terms of the injunction.[7] Also, the courts consider property acquired through a breach to be subject to a constructive trust, and they therefore require the offending party to disclose and deliver to the plaintiff all the benefits acquired through the trust.[8] The defendant may usually choose between delivery up and destruction. If destruction is chosen, then the defendant must swear an affidavit confirming that destruction has taken place.

The court may also decide to grant an order for delivery up where the defendant has acted in a high-handed or dishonest manner.[9] The subject of an order for delivery up or destruction will obviously include items the defendant has actually taken, but may also include items the defendant has made or caused to be made using the wrongfully acquired business secrets.

To date there have been no decided cases where confidential information was recovered by invoking either Rule 44 of the Ontario Rules of Civil Procedure or Rule 470 of the Federal Court Rules. It is questionable whether such a remedy would be available in the case of confidential information since the courts have specifically refrained from recognizing confidential information as a form of property.
See, for example, Rules of Civil Procedure, R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 194, Rule 44; and Hotspex Inc. v. Edwards, 2011 ONSC 3837.
